overview: This Act makes the women's court pilot program in the first circuit permanent. [8] It establishes a three-year women's court pilot program in the circuit court of the Kona division of the third circuit, which is intended to acknowledge the distinct pathways that lead women into the criminal justice system and address their individualized needs. [8] The Act also requires the judiciary to submit a report to the legislature regarding the need for and the associated costs of a pilot program for women's court in the second and fifth circuits and Hilo division of the third circuit. [8]
appropriations: There is appropriated out of the general revenues of the State of Hawaii the sum of $514,900 (HB727_SD1_.HTM.txt) or so much thereof as may be necessary for fiscal year 2025-2026 and $557,000 (HB727_SD1_.HTM.txt) or so much thereof as may be necessary for fiscal year 2026-2027. [8] The sums are for mental health, substance abuse treatment, and other services; and the establishment of two temporary positions for the women's court pilot program. [8] The sums appropriated shall be expended by the judiciary for the purposes of this Act. [8]
assumptions_and_methodology: The Judiciary's proposal for the Kona Women's Court is based on a detailed budget for a multi-year pilot project. [7] Testimony to the Senate Committee on Ways and Means outlines a three-year pilot program budget with annual costs of $514,900 (HB727_SD1_TESTIMONY_WAM_03-31-25_.PDF.txt) for Year 1, $547,000 (HB727_SD1_TESTIMONY_WAM_03-31-25_.PDF.txt) for Year 2, and $515,000 (HB727_SD1_TESTIMONY_WAM_03-31-25_.PDF.txt) for Year 3. [7] [7] [7] The appropriations in the bill align with the first two years of the Judiciary's proposed costs, which include contracted services for mental health professionals, behavioral health beds, cultural practitioners, therapy, and increased drug testing, as well as costs for staff, training, and technology. [7] [7] [7] [7] [7]
agency_impact: The women's court pilot program shall be established within the third circuit Kona division of the judiciary. [8] The women's court pilot program shall be under the supervision of the big island drug court. [8] This structure will leverage the existing BIDC structure and staff at the outset, allowing the Third Circuit to supplement existing drug court services in Kona. [7] The judiciary is also required to submit a report to the legislature regarding the need for and associated costs of a pilot program in other circuits. [8]
economic_impact: The goal of the pilot program is to divert participants from incarceration, supporting their success in the community, and reducing recidivism. [8] This measure will support women in the State dealing with trauma, abuse, unhealthy relationships, and more by providing substance abuse treatment, mental health support, and assistance with navigating the criminal and social services systems. [9] By reducing recidivism and prioritizing rehabilitation over incarceration, HB 727 will increase public safety and strengthen our community. [7]
policy_impact: This Act makes the Women's Court Pilot Program in the First Circuit permanent by amending Act 243, Session Laws of Hawaii 2022, and removing its repeal date. [8] The measure establishes a three-year Women's Court Pilot Program in the circuit court of the Kona division of the Third Circuit, rather than the Second and Fifth Circuits as previously proposed. [9] It also deletes the requirement for an interim study in the Third Circuit and instead requires the Judiciary to submit a report on the need for and associated costs of a pilot program for women's court in the second and fifth circuits and Hilo division of the third circuit. [8] [9]
revenue_sources: The bill appropriates funds out of the general revenues of the State of Hawaii. [8] The sum of $514,900 (HB727_SD1_.HTM.txt) is appropriated for fiscal year 2025-2026. [8] The sum of $557,000 (HB727_SD1_.HTM.txt) is appropriated for fiscal year 2026-2027. [8]
six_year_fiscal_implications: The Act makes the Women's Court Pilot Program in the First Circuit permanent, which will create ongoing fiscal obligations beyond the six-year period. [8] For the new pilot program, the bill appropriates $514,900 (HB727_SD1_.HTM.txt) for fiscal year 2025-2026 and $557,000 (HB727_SD1_.HTM.txt) for fiscal year 2026-2027. [8] Part III of the Act, which establishes the Kona pilot program, is repealed on June 30, 2028. [8] The Judiciary's three-year budget proposal anticipates costs of $514,900 (HB727_SD1_TESTIMONY_WAM_03-31-25_.PDF.txt) in Year 1, $547,000 (HB727_SD1_TESTIMONY_WAM_03-31-25_.PDF.txt) in Year 2, and $515,000 (HB727_SD1_TESTIMONY_WAM_03-31-25_.PDF.txt) in Year 3. [7] [7] [7] The total cost for the three-year pilot is projected in testimony to be $1,576,900 (HB727_SD1_TESTIMONY_WAM_03-31-25_.PDF.txt). [7] Annual costs in the testimony include a Women's Mental Health Professional at $175,000 (HB727_SD1_TESTIMONY_WAM_03-31-25_.PDF.txt), Womens Behavioral Health Beds at $100,000 (HB727_SD1_TESTIMONY_WAM_03-31-25_.PDF.txt), a Kona Drug Court Probation Supervisor at $85,000 (HB727_SD1_TESTIMONY_WAM_03-31-25_.PDF.txt), a Peer Specialist at $80,000 (HB727_SD1_TESTIMONY_WAM_03-31-25_.PDF.txt), and other services. [7] Training costs are estimated at $5,000 (HB727_SD1_TESTIMONY_WAM_03-31-25_.PDF.txt) in Year 1 and $42,000 (HB727_SD1_TESTIMONY_WAM_03-31-25_.PDF.txt) in Year 2. [7] Technology costs are estimated at $4,900 (HB727_SD1_TESTIMONY_WAM_03-31-25_.PDF.txt) in Year 1. [7] The Judiciary will also submit a report in 2026 regarding the costs of potential future pilot programs. [8]
operating_revenue_impact: The provided documents do not describe any anticipated impacts on operating revenues. [8] The program is supported by appropriations from the general revenues of the State of Hawaii. [8] There is no indication that the program will generate its own revenue stream. [8]
Full_Time_Equivalent_Positions: The bill provides for the establishment of two temporary positions. [8] This includes one full-time equivalent (1.0 FTE) Kona drug court probation supervisor position. [8] It also includes one full-time equivalent (1.0 FTE) peer specialist position. [8]
capital_expenditure_impact: The measure does not appropriate funds for major capital expenditures. [8] However, the Judiciary's budget proposal includes a request for technology costs totaling $4,900 (HB727_HD1_TESTIMONY_JDC_03-19-25_.PDF.txt). [7] These costs include a Computer Workstation for $1,200 (HB727_HD1_TESTIMONY_JDC_03-19-25_.PDF.txt), a computer for the Kona Probation Supervisor for $1,000 (HB727_HD1_TESTIMONY_JDC_03-19-25_.PDF.txt), and other minor equipment. [7]
fiscal_implications_after_6_years: The Act makes the women's court pilot program in the first circuit permanent, which will result in ongoing fiscal obligations beyond the six-year timeframe. [8] Part III of the Act, which establishes the three-year women's court pilot program in the Kona division of the third circuit, shall be repealed on June 30, 2028. [8] Any fiscal implications for the Kona program beyond this date would require further legislative action. [8]
updates_from_previous_fiscal_note: This measure has been significantly amended. [9] It now makes the Women's Court Pilot Program in the First Circuit permanent. [9] It establishes a three-year Women's Court Pilot Program in the circuit court of the Kona division of the Third Circuit, rather than establishing pilots in the Second and Fifth Circuits. [9] Consequently, the requirement for the Third Circuit to conduct an interim study has been deleted and replaced with the active pilot program. [9] Specific appropriations of $514,900 (HB727_SD1_.HTM.txt) for FY 2025-2026 and $557,000 (HB727_SD1_.HTM.txt) for FY 2026-2027 from general revenues have been inserted for the Kona pilot, and two temporary 1.0 FTE positions are established. [8] [8]
